column4: So, I'm looking at this article here: http://www.linuxquestions.org/linux/answers/Applications_GUI_Multimedia/How_To_Do_Eveything_With_DD
Which basically just gives like a thousand different really really cool and interesting things you can do with dd

And I notice he's doing a lot of "dd if=/proc/<STUFF>" and piping it to hexdump and then less. I'm wondering why he's doing that... I mean, why not just do "cat /proc/meminfo" instead of "dd if=/proc/meminfo | hexdump -C | less" (which, not to mention... does not even give you formatted (thus very readable) text). Is he just doing it because you can just "do it" for the sake of it, or is there a reason to do it?
Please don't flood; use http://paste.ubuntu.com to paste; don't use Enter as punctuation.
